question:
H119 Culinary Management – Nutrition (2 years, Ontario College Diploma)

Starting Months: September
Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)
Credential Type: Ontario College Diploma
Campus: St. James Campus
Program Code: H119
Method of Study: Full-time

Program Description:
The Culinary Management – Nutrition program at CHCA focuses on the business side of the food industry while also providing students with a strong foundation in nutrition and dietetics. Students will gain hands-on experience in our state-of-the-art facilities, including our teaching kitchens, student restaurant, and laboratories. The curriculum covers topics such as menu planning, food costing, inventory control, customer service, and human resource management. In addition, students will explore the principles of nutrition, food science, and diet therapy, preparing them for careers in a variety of settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, schools, and corporations.

Program Structure:
The program is structured into four semesters, with each semester consisting of two 7-week terms. Students will spend their time in a combination of classroom lectures, laboratory sessions, and hands-on practical experiences. They will also participate in field placements and industry tours to gain valuable real-world exposure.

Program Highlights:
- State-of-the-art facilities, including teaching kitchens, student restaurant, and laboratories
- Opportunities for field placements and industry tours
- A strong focus on both culinary management and nutrition
- Hands-on learning experiences in a supportive environment
- Access to experienced instructors and industry professionals
- Preparation for careers in various food service sectors, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, schools, and corporations

Related Programs:
- Culinary Management (H100)
- Food and Nutrition Management (Postgraduate) (H402)
- Culinary Management (Integrated Learning) (H116)

Admission Requirements:
To be eligible for admission to the Culinary Management – Nutrition program, applicants must have a minimum overall average of 65% in their Grade 12 English, Mathematics, and one Science or Arts course. They must also complete the following prerequisites:
- Grade 11 or 12 Foods and Nutrition (minimum of 30 hours)
- Grade 11 or 12 Introduction to Business Studies or Business Fundamentals (minimum of 30 hours)

Note: Admission to the program is competitive, and meeting the minimum requirements does not guarantee acceptance.

Fees:
Domestic Students: $7,819.00 per year *
International Students: $21,195.00 per year **

* Domestic tuition may be eligible for a $1000 entrance award.
** International tuition is subject to change.

Experiential Learning:
The Culinary Management – Nutrition program incorporates experiential learning opportunities throughout the curriculum, providing students with hands-on experience in real-world settings. These opportunities include field placements, industry tours, and practical applications of culinary and nutritional skills in our teaching kitchens and student restaurant. Students will also participate in group projects, case studies, and simulations to deepen their understanding of the material and develop essential skills for success in their future careers.?

context:
The Culinary Management – Nutrition program is offered at George Brown College. It provides training in food and nutrition-focused environments such as restaurants, resorts, schools, spas, seniors' residences and long-term care facilities. Students learn through demonstrations, lectures, and hands-on culinary practice, and complete a seven-week industry work-integrated learning experience in their final semester. The program operates from Monday to Friday with classes that may begin as early as 7 a.m. and run until 10 p.m.

Graduates of this program can expect careers in various organizations related to food and nutrition, including restaurants, hotels, spas, resorts, schools, manufacturers, health and fitness facilities, seniors' residences and long-term care facilities, as well as the opportunity to start their own business as an entrepreneur.

George Brown College also offers a postgraduate Food and Nutrition Management Program (H402) for students who wish to take their careers to the next level in health care and nutrition. This one-year graduate certificate program is accredited.

context:
The H402 Food and Nutrition Management program is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management. The following are the required courses for the program spread over four semesters:

Semester 1:
- HOSF1029: Theory of Food 1
- HOST1068: Smart Serve
- HOSF1294: Nutrition And Wellness
- HOSF1229: Nutrition Analysis and Food Labelling
- HOSF1247: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Foundations
- HOSF1248: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Essentials
- HOSF1145: Sanitation
- HOSF1146: Emergency First Aid/Heartsaver CPR (weekend course)
- MATH1200: Culinary Math Essentials
- COMM2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- GSCI1035: Science of Sustainability

Semester 2:
- HOSF1257: Nutrition and Culture
- HOSF1191: Culinary Nutrition - Desserts
- HOSF1249: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Cultures I
- HOSF1250: Culinary Nutrition Skills – Cultures II
- HOSF1226: Introduction to the Science of Food
- HOST1005: Food, Beverage and Labour Cost Control (Hybrid)
- HOSF2040: Advanced Sanitation
- HOST 1126: Career Preparation
- HOSF 1287: WHMIS
- GNED: General Education Elective

Semester 3:
- HOSF1156: Nutrition for Life
- HOSF2036: Menu Applications
- HOSF2037: Introduction to Quality Assurance
- HOSF2069: Culinary Nutrition for Life I
- HOSF2056: Introduction to Industry Research Project
- HOSF2081: Hospitality Leadership and Communication
- HOSF2070: Culinary Nutrition for Life II

Semester 4:
- HOSF1159: Chef’s Kitchen
- HOSF2041: Fundamentals of Wine and Service
- HOSF2042: Quantity Cooking for Nutrition Issues
- HOSF2043: Nutrition Issues
- HOSF2057: Capstone Project

* denotes courses with an asterisk are likely to be practical or lab-based.
question:
It appears that the H402 Food and Nutrition Management program at Conestoga College in Canada is a comprehensive culinary nutrition program that covers both the theoretical and practical aspects of food and nutrition. The program is accredited by the Canadian Society of Nutrition Management.

The program consists of 16 semester courses spread over four semesters. In the first semester, students take foundational courses in food theory, sanitation, emergency first aid, CPR, math, communication skills, and sustainability. They also begin their culinary nutrition studies with foundations and essentials courses, as well as starting their nutritional analysis and food labelling course.

In the second semester, students explore nutrition and culture, desserts, culinary nutrition skills for different cultures, and science of food. They also learn cost control, advanced sanitation, career preparation, WHMIS, and general education electives.

The third semester focuses on nutrition for life, menu applications, quality assurance, the industry research project, hospitality leadership and communication, and culinary nutrition for life I & II.

In the fourth semester, students participate in a chef's kitchen, wine and service, quantity cooking for nutrition issues, and various nutrition issues. They also complete their capstone project.

Many of these courses, denoted with an asterisk, are likely to be practical or lab-based, providing students with hands-on experience in the culinary field while they learn about food and nutrition.?

question:
Title: Hospitality and Service Management - Culinary Arts Program Overview

The Hospitality and Service Management - Culinary Arts program is designed to equip students with advanced culinary skills for various food service environments, along with essential business principles and sustainability practices. Here's a brief overview of the program.

Prerequisites: Students may be required to take COMM 1000 as a prerequisite before certain communication courses. For more information, please visit the Assessment Centre.

Program Structure: The Hospitality and Service Management - Culinary Arts program includes General Education Electives, which consist of a seven-week course, as well as specialized culinary arts courses. Some of these courses are:

1. HOSF2043 - Nutrition Issues
2. HOSF2057 - Culinary Industry Research and Development (Interactive Lab)
3. HOSF2075 - Industry Externship

Skills to Learn: Students are expected to master various skills including advanced culinary planning, preparation, presentation for different food service environments, applying food science, maintaining kitchen environment, ensuring safe kitchen operations, creating menus reflecting nutrition knowledge, managing food service operations, using technology for food production, and performing effectively as a team member.

Business Principles: Additionally, students will learn business principles, costing practices, sustainability, ethics, local food sourcing, and food security to become well-rounded professionals in the culinary industry.

Courses under this program offer hands-on learning experiences that allow students to develop both their technical skills and broader knowledge of the hospitality industry. Students will learn essential skills necessary for a successful career in various aspects of the culinary field, including management, operations, food service, and more.?

George Brown College Admissions Information:

**Domestic Applicants:**
- Apply through Ontario Colleges.
- Minimum grades required for admission may vary depending on the program.
- Course exemptions may be granted based on college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
- For inquiries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, or the admissions process, contact the Admissions Office at [admissions@georgebrown.ca](mailto:admissions@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Admissions web page.
- Contact George Brown College by calling 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002, or contact one of their international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through a virtual meeting or inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
- Visit George Brown College's campus for Discovery Days to learn more about areas of interest and meet with representatives. Sign up for an Open House Discovery Day and explore related programs like Culinary Management (H100) and Food and Nutrition Management (Postgraduate).

**International Applicants:**
- Apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
- Minimum grades required for admission may vary depending on the program and country of origin.
- International students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
- For financial aid and fees-related inquiries, contact the Financial Aid Office at [FinAid@georgebrown.ca](mailto:FinAid@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Financial Aid web page.
- Inquiries about the Culinary Management-Nutrition (H119) program should be directed to [CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca](mailto:CHCAStudentSupport@georgebrown.ca).
- Contact George Brown College by calling 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002, or contact one of their international recruitment representatives specializing by country of origin through a virtual meeting or inquiry on the International Contact Us page.
- Students with allergens such as nuts, dairy, and shellfish should be aware that they are used in practical labs. George Brown College is sensitive to religious observances but may not meet specific dietary laws related to halal and kosher foods.

**Application Deadlines:**
- Applications for Fall term (September start) usually open in October the previous year and close on February 1, while Winter term (January start) applications typically open in mid-September and close in late November or early December.

**Program Information:**
- Culinary Management (H100): A two-year program that covers fundamental culinary techniques as well as management skills for careers in the food service industry.
- Food and Nutrition Management (Postgraduate): A one-year graduate diploma program designed to provide students with the knowledge and skills necessary to design, implement, manage, and evaluate food service operations in a variety of settings.

**Campus Locations:**
- St. James Campus: 251 Dundas Street East, Toronto, Ontario M5A 1Z3 (Culinary Management and Food and Nutrition Management programs)
- Waterfront Campus: 51 Dockside Drive, Toronto, Ontario M5A 0B4 (Culinary Management program)

**Student Services:**
- Financial Aid: Offers a range of financial assistance options to help students pay for their education.
- Health and Wellness: Provides access to health services and supports mental, emotional, and physical wellbeing.
- International Student Support: Helps international students navigate their studies at George Brown College.
- Accessibility Services: Ensures equal access to campus facilities and programs for students with disabilities.
- Career Services: Offers resources to help students find employment during and after their studies.

**Partnerships:**
- George Brown College has partnerships with several organizations, including The Toronto Food Terminal and the Canadian Culinary Federation. These partnerships provide opportunities for students to gain industry experience and build professional networks.?

question:
Title: Centennial College - Culinary Management Programs

Centennial College offers various culinary management programs designed to provide students with the necessary skills and knowledge to excel in the food industry. The college is known for its innovative facilities and experienced teachers. Here's a brief overview of the programs offered:

1. Culinary Management (H100)
This two-year Ontario College Diploma program focuses on practical culinary skills, nutrition education, management principles, and food safety regulations. Students will gain hands-on experience in Centennial's modern kitchen facilities and learn from experienced industry professionals.

2. Food and Nutrition Management (Postgraduate) (H402)
This one-year Ontario College Graduate Certificate program is designed for individuals with a diploma or degree in culinary management, nutrition, or a related field. Students will gain advanced knowledge in food science, nutrition analysis, menu planning, and event coordination.

3. Culinary Management (Integrated Learning) (H116)
This apprenticeship program is designed for students who want to work while they learn. It combines on-the-job training with theoretical instruction in a classroom setting. Students will gain practical experience in various foodservice establishments and earn a diploma from Centennial College upon completion of the program.

Testimonial:
"Centennial College has given me the opportunity to thrive in my culinary career through its state-of-the-art facilities and experienced teachers. The H119 Culinary Management and Nutritional Education program provided me with a solid foundation in both culinary skills and nutrition education, which I use daily in my profession." - Khadija Atcha, Centennial College Diploma holder

Additional Information:
Centennial College offers campus tours, information sessions, and tailored resources for applicants. Interested individuals can sign up using their first name, last name, email, domestic or international status, and country to receive more information about the programs and application process.?
